sub_topic: Probability of a certain type of traffic accident occurring on a road
message_1: What is the probability of a fatal head-on collision occurring on a particular road, given that this type of accident occurs on that road once every 10 years on average?
message_2:
To calculate the probability of a fatal head-on collision occurring on a particular road, we can use the concept of the Poisson distribution. The Poisson distribution is used to model the number of events (in this case, fatal head-on collisions) occurring in a fixed interval of time or space.

Let λ (lambda) be the average rate of fatal head-on collisions per year. In this case, λ = 1/10, since there is one fatal head-on collision every 10 years on average.

The probability of a fatal head-on collision occurring in a given year can be calculated using the Poisson probability formula:

P(X = k) = (e^(-λ) * λ^k) / k!

where:
- P(X = k) is the probability of k fatal head-on collisions occurring in a given year
- e is the base of the natural logarithm (approximately 2.71828)
- λ is the average rate of fatal head-on collisions per year
- k is the number of fatal head-on collisions we want to find the probability for (in this case, k = 1)

Plugging in the values, we get:

P(X = 1) = (e^(-1/10) * (1/10)^1) / 1!

P(X = 1) ≈ (0.904837 * 0.1) / 1

P(X = 1) ≈ 0.0904837

So, the probability of a fatal head-on collision occurring on the particular road in a given year is approximately 9.05%.
